Award.AwardTitle: Cosmology with the galaxy bispectrum: galaxy bias, redshift-space distortion, and primordial non-Gaussianity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the growth and evolution of structure in the Universe is a key component of developing an accurate model of the Universe as a whole. In order to do this, large surveys of galaxies are needed. The goal of this research is to develop new analysis/interpretation tools for current and future large-scale cosmological galaxy surveys such as HETDEX (Hobby-Eberly Telescope Dark Energy Experiment) and eBOSS (Extended Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey). Broader impacts of the work include training of two graduate students and a postdoc, and development of a new presentation focusing on the large-scale structure of the Universe for the outreach program of the Department of Astronomy & Astrophysics at Penn State.

The research will emphasize the galaxy bispectrum, the Fourier transform of the galaxy three-point correlation function, to constrain primordial non-Gaussianity and the non-linear physics of structure growth. Three projects are proposed, including an investigation of the accuracy of theoretical predictions based on many different forms of advanced perturbation theory compared to N-body simulations, a detailed analysis of survey window functions, and analytic approximations for covariance matrices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The galaxy bispectrum will be a powerful probe of the large-scale structure formation, physics of the early Universe, as well as astrophysics such as galaxy formation. Throughout the study supported by this grant, the PI?s team has equipped with the necessary tools for the measurement and interpretation of the galaxy bispectrum, three-point correlation function in Fourier space. We have advanced for all three components: theoretical prediction of the bispectrum, including observational realities, and modeling the uncertainties (covariance matrix), and ready to measure and interpret the galaxy bispectrum with, for example, eBOSS Quasars and HETDEX Lyman-alpha emitters.


Along the way, the PI?s team has published fifteen peer-reviewed research papers, and two papers are under review at the moment. In particular, the PI has published an extensive (about 200 pages) review article summarize and clarify the perturbative bias expansion scheme that relates observations (the observed galaxy density) to theory (the underlying matter density). To test the impact of the observing conditions, the PI has developed the lognormal simulations whose underlying statistics are known precisely. The PI has also developed the novel data modeling scheme of Grid-based standard perturbation theory (GridSPT) technique with which we can flexibly incorporate various observing conditions into the analysis. Besides publishing these key results, we have also released the software implementation of the lognormal simulation, and a fast method of calculating correlation function (two-fast algorithm) and estimating the galaxy bispectrum in the publicly available git repository. Anyone interested in can download the software and run it by themselves.


This grant was critical for providing the financial support of two junior cosmologists. Dr. Nishant Agarwal, who was a postdoctoral scholar supported by this grant, took a job as a junior faculty in the University of Massachusetts at Lowell. The graduate student Henry S. Grasshorn Gebhardt, who was also supported by this grant, successfully defended his thesis and started a new job as the Nasa Postdoctoral Program fellow at Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The grant supported a total of four undergraduate students through the REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates) supplement funds. Among them, three senior students are pursuing their graduate degree in Physics and Astronomy (two are already in the graduate school, one is applying), and one junior student will apply for the Astronomy graduate program in the year 2020. Reaching out to the general public, the PI and students participated in various department-wide outreach activities, including ASTROFest, ASTRO on tap, Solar eclipse viewing event, as well as the roof-top observing nights. The PIs group has also documented a manual for the party-view program so that the public outreach program using the HETDEX galaxies will be ready as the data from the HETDEX survey will be completing.
